key_title: Key to the families of Monocotyledons

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria

leads.lead_text: Aquatic plants, floating free on or near the water surface, not rooting in substrate
Land or aquatic plants, if aquatic and with floating leaves then rooting in substrate

Plant consisting of small (less than 1 cm long) flat or flattened ovoid leaf or thallus, with or without simple roots from undersurface; plants readily reproducing vegetatively by lateral buds; flowers produced in small pits on upper surface, microscopic and rarely observed
Plants conspicuous, with leaves c. 5 cm long or more, the petioles much inflated and spongy, roots abundant, feathery; flowers conspicuous (c. 5 cm diam.), mauve, produced in spikes
Marine aquatics, or aquatics of non-marine habitats with leaves permanently submerged, but inflorescence sometimes emergent from water
Terrestrial or semi-aquatic plants, or aquatics with leaves floating or emergent from water
Plants of marine or brackish habitats
Plants of fresh water
Leaves ligulate
Leaves without ligules
Plants of brackish habitats (including estuaries, rarely extending to the intertidal zone); leaves 1 mm wide or less; flowers unisexual, solitary or clustered in axils
Marine plants of deep waters and rock-pools; leaves at least 4 mm wide
[link through]
Leaf blade and sheath shed leaving a circular scar; flowers unisexual, enclosed within leaf-sheaths
Leaf blade shed but sheath persistent and fibrous; flowers bisexual, in several terminal spikes
[link through]
[link through]
Leaves elliptic to ovate, c. 1 cm wide or more; flowers with perianth (males with 3 segments, females with 6)
Leaves narrow linear, to 1 mm wide; flowers without perianth
Flowers bisexual, borne at the end of a long, spirally coiled peduncle
Flowers unisexual, in short spikes, remaining enclosed in sheathing leaf-bases
Flowers bisexual, in emergent spikes; perianth segments 4
Flowers unisexual, remaining submerged; perianth segments 0, 3 or 6
[link through]
Leaves ovate to linear, mostly much more than 1 mm wide, but if ever less, then with finely toothed margins
Leaves narrow-linear, less than 1 mm wide, with entire margins
[link through]

Flowers lacking perianth, packed in thickish spike, subtended and partially enclosed by a tubular bract (spathe), margins overlapping or connate at base; apical part of spike male only or with a sterile appendix, lower part of spike female or bisexual; fleshy usually rhizomatous herb, usually near swamps or watercourses
Flowers with a perianth or if perianth lacking, flowers not arranged in spatheate spikes
Flowers unisexual
Flowers bisexual

Flowers inconspicuous, often minute, subtended (and often enclosed by) paired or solitary, overlapping bracts or scales, in heads or spikelets; perianth absent or of 1–8 scales or bristles, usually concealed within bracts
Flowers conspicuous (but not always coloured), or if inconspicuous at least with distinct perianth parts
Male and female flowers small, mixed in spherical heads 2–8 mm diam., lacking conspicuous bracts; mostly marsh or aquatic plants
Flowers in spikelets surrounded by glume-like bracts
[link through]
Wiry plants with jointed stems; leaves reduced to sheathing bracts (bracts overlapping at base); male and female plants separate (except sometimes in Lepyrodia)
Leaves well developped, or if ever reduced to sheathing bracts then these fused at the base and plants with both male and female flowers or flowers bisexual
Tiny, tufted annuals; male and female flowers mixed in terminal heads subtended and exceeded by 2–6 equal or subequal bracts
Habit various; if inflorescence ever a terminal head then flowers bisexual
Inflorescence green or greenish, with a pair of prominent, erect sheathing bracts enclosing the flowers and their small, membranous, subtending bracts
Inflorescence red, flower cluster subtended by 4–6 more or less equal sheathing bracts, individual flowers (ovaries and stamens) not subtended by bracts
[link through]

Flowers arranged in cylindric or distichous spikelets or spikes (rarely 1-flowered), rarely subtended by a pair of sterile bracts; individual flowers subtended by a solitary bract (glume); leaf-sheath usually with fused margins; stems cylindric, flattened or 3-sided, with solid internodes (sedges)

Flowers arranged in distichous (sometimes 1-flowered) spikelets, usually subtended by a pair of sterile bracts (glumes); individual flowers enclosed by a pair of bracts (lemma and palea), or if ever only one bract present, then fertile flowers only 1 per spikelet; leaf-sheath usually with free margins; stems usually cylindric, with hollow internodes (grasses)
Plants monoecious, male flowers borne above females in inflorescence; aquatic or semi-aquatic plants
Plants dioecious; mostly terrestrial
Perianth segments not petaloid; flowers sessile, in spikes or globular clusters; leaves linear, flattened or triangular in cross-section
Perianth segments in 2 distinct whorls, the outermost petaloid; flowers pedicellate, whorled; at least the emergent leaves with a distinct ovate to sagittate blade
Climbers, usually with retrorse spines along stems; leaves ovate, with prominent reticulate venation; eastern Victoria only
Non-climbers, or, if plants every climbing then venation linear, lacking prominent reticulate venation
Leaves well-developed; perianth segments more or less membranous or somewhat fleshy; fruit containing 1–few seeds
Leaves reduced to sheathing bracts; perianth segments scarious; fruit containing many small seeds
Carpels not fused or shortly united at base only
Carpels united for the greater part or carpel solitary
Tufted annuals or perennials, less than 10 cm high; land plants (but often growing near water)
Perennials, more than 10 cm high; aquatic or marsh plants
Inflorescence green or greenish, with a pair of prominent, erect sheathing bracts enclosing the flowers and their small, membranous, subtending bracts
Inflorescence red, flower cluster subtended by 4–6 more or less equal sheathing bracts, individual flowers (ovaries and stamens) not subtended by bracts
[link through]
Flowers borne in once-forked spikes; perianth of a single white segment; anthers 6–12, purple; carpels 3–6
Flowers borne in simple spikes or panicles; perianth of 3 or more segments (but inconspicuous in Juncaginaceae)
[link through]
Perianth segments, stamens and carpels each 4
Perianth segments, stamens and carpels not each 4
[link through]
Perianth segments in 2 distinct whorls, the outermost petaloid; at least the emergent leaves with a distinct ovate to sagittate blade
Perianth segments all similar, not petaloid; leaves linear, terete or strap-shaped
Ovary superior or perianth of petals and/or sepals absent
Ovary inferior, perianth well-developed

Flowers inconspicuous, often minute, within imbricate bracts or scales (glumes), in spikelets; perianth absent or of 18 scales or bristles, usually concealed within bracts (chiefly grasses and sedges)
Flowers conspicuous (but not always coloured), or if inconspicuous at least with distinct perianth parts rather than scales or bristles

Tiny, tufted plants; male and female flowers mixed in terminal heads subtended and exceeded by 2–6 equal or subequal bracts; individual flowers sometimes separated by a minute membranous bract; fruit a dehiscent, 1-seeded capsule
Plants various, if ever male and female flowers mixed in heads then bracts (glumes) separating individual flowers conspicuous; fruit indehiscent, 1-seeded
Inflorescence green or greenish, with a pair of prominent, erect sheathing bracts enclosing the flowers; individual flowers separated by a minute membranous bract
Inflorescence reddish, with 2 or 3 pairs of equal sheathing bracts enclosing the flowers; individual flowers not subtended by bracts
[link through]

Flowers arranged in cylindric or distichous spikelets or spikes (rarely 1-flowered), rarely subtended by a pair of sterile bracts; individual flowers subtended by a solitary bract (glume); leaf-sheath usually with fused margins; stems cylindric, flattened or 3-sided (sedges)

Flowers arranged in distichous (sometimes 1-flowered) spikelets, usually subtended by a pair of sterile bracts (glumes); individual flowers enclosed by a pair of bracts (lemma and palea), or if ever only one bract present, then fertile flowers only 1 per spikelet; leaf-sheath usually with free margins; stems usually cylindric, with hollow internodes (grasses)
Perianth segments 4 (inner pair small); stamen 1; uncommon yellow-flowered, tufted semi-aquatic
Perianth segments 6
[link through]
Leaves compound; stems massive, woody, erect and undivided (palms)
Leaves simple or absent
Perianth sepaloid (green, brown or translucent)
Perianth petaloid (white or coloured), but sometimes segments small
Carpels fused; style solitary, with 3 stigmas
Carpels free or nearly so; stigmas sessile
Stamens 3
Stamens 6 (sometimes 3 much longer than others)

Rhizome bright red; leaves tufted, linear, to 1.2 m long, plicate; scape up to 2.5 m tall; inflorescence a dense cylindircal panicle, with numerous yellow flowers; style and lowermost anther turned sideways
Rhizome absent or not conspicuously bright red, but if ever somewhat reddish, neither with leaves long and plicate nor with scape approaching 2 m high
[link through]
Inner perianth segments united; flowers short-lived with yellowish, tissue-like petals; inflorescence a dense spherical head on an undivided, wiry scape
Inner perianth segments free; other features in combination not as above
[link through]

Tufted plants, stems commonly annual, or if prostrate, scrambling or twining, then either leafless or leaves sessile; rhizomatous or with a bulbous or cormous rootstock; inflorescence a raceme or panicle, not subtended by spathe-like bracts

Prostrate, scrambling, much-branched plant with perennial, succulent stems; leaves ovate with sheathing petioles; rooting readily from nodes; inflorescence of 1ew flowers subtended by a single or pair of spathe-like bracts
Aquatic plants; flowers mauve and yellow in a terminal spike-like raceme; leaf-blade ovate, on long petiole
Land plants, rarely growing in marshy situations and then with features not as above

Tufted plants, stems commonly annual, or if prostrate, scrambling or twining, then either leafless or leaves sessile; rhizomatous or with a bulbous or cormous rootstock; inflorescence a raceme or panicle, not subtended by spathe-like bracts

Prostrate, scrambling, much-branched plant with perennial, succulent stems; leaves ovate with sheathing petioles; rooting readily from nodes; inflorescence of 1-few flowers subtended by a single or pair of spathe-like bracts
Flower lacking labellum; stamens 3 or 6, not assoicated with the style
Flower usually with distinct labellum; stamens 1, united with style or style held between anther locules
Aquatic plants with leaf-blades ovate, floating on water surface; flowers emergent or floating, showy, whitish with red-purple blotch at base; submerged cleistogamous flowers also produced
Terrestrial plants, or if semi-aquatic, then leaf blades more or less linear and emergent from water
Stamens 3
Stamens 6
Mostly leafy herbs, always with chlorophyll (i.e. some parts green), growing and flowering above ground level
Leafless herbs without chlorophyll (i.e. with no green parts), growing and flowering within leaf-litter layer of wet, shaded forests
Flowers zygomorphic, perianth tubular, externally tomentose; inflorescence a one-sided raceme
Flowers actinomorphic, or if zygomorphic then features not as above
[link through]
[link through]
Labellum derived from modified perianth segment; stamen and style united, with stamen distal to style
Labellum derived from staminodes; style held between anther locules, the style extending beyond the anther
[link through]
